mentions.context: BMA was chosen in particular because it reduces overconfidence and is relatively robust against model misspecification [47,[49][50][51].
The tidyverse package (version 1.3.2) was used [20].
A total of 6 BMA analyses were conducted, with 3 (both sexes, male, and female) for TM use and 3 for TM willingness.
Regarding priors for BMA, we assumed that all candidate models were equally likely a priori (same prior weight).
The default priors in rstanarm 2.21.1 are designed to be weakly informative.

For more details about the BMA analysis, please refer to Multimedia Appendix 4, which synthesizes BMA results for the top 5 models, as well as to Figures S7-S11 in Multimedia Appendix 6 for TM use and for TM willingness, which represent all the variables considered (in the y-axis) for the full list of models selected (in the x-axis).
The spider charts were created using the fmsb package (version 0.7.3) [26].
The selection of the "best" model through BMA was undertaken using the BMA package (version 3.18.15)
A total of 16 answers were selected using BMA.
Bayesian estimation was performed using the rstanarm package (version 2.21.1) [22,23].
Finally, we used the remaining variables with BMA for model selection and identification of determinants.
Results for the "best" model identified through BMA indicated that being female (OR 0.57, 95% CI 0.35-0.90;
Posterior distributions were described using the bayestestR package (version 0.12.1) [24].
Figure 2 presents the determinants identified through BMA for the 6 analyses.
The selection of the "best" model through BMA was undertaken using the BMA package (version 3.18.15) [25].
The "best" model (ie, model with the highest posterior probability) from BMA was detailed.

Determinant factors, defined as variables with a posterior probability of ≥10% with BMA, were identified and used to establish the profile of individuals using or willing to use TM and the profile of individuals not using or not willing to use TM. Figure 3 presents the profiles identified based on gender.
Markov chain Monte Carlo was used to deal with the intractable computational challenge of BMA that comes from the candidate model enumeration [52].

For more details about the BMA analysis, please refer to Multimedia Appendix 4, which synthesizes BMA results for the top 5 models, as well as to Figures S7-S11 in Multimedia Appendix 6 for TM use and for TM willingness, which represent all the variables considered (in the y-axis) for the full list of models selected (in the x-axis).
Finally, the determinants of TM use and TM willingness were identified through Bayesian model averaging (BMA) [19].

In addition, determinant factors (question answers), defined as variables with a posterior probability of ≥10% with BMA, were identified and used to establish the profile of the individuals using or willing to use TM and the profile of the individuals not using or not willing to use TM using spider charts.
